title: Can I justify my axiom by proving an existing theorem? - Quora

response.answer_text: If it's an existing theorem, then someone was already able to prove it without the help of “your” axiom. So probably your axiom is a consequence of the normally assumed axioms, or alternatively your proof may just be invalid.

Not necessarily. If the axiom does not relate to the theorem being proved, then there is no justification for it. The axiom would be justified if you cannot prove the theorem without it - that may be hard since it depends on you being sure you can’t prove the theorem without the axiom. You also need to show that the axiom is not redundant, that is the axiom is not implied by other axioms.
If the existing theorem was proved using an axiom not in your system, and you can prove it using your axiom instead, then this helps justify your axiom.
